sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment (inhalation route): no adjustment necessary
  • renal impairment (CrCl 10 to 30 mL/min/1.73 m(2)): initial, 1 to 2 g; maintenance, 0.5 times the usual initial dose
  • renal impairment (CrCl less than 10 mL/min/1.73 m(2)): initial, 0.5 to 2 g; maintenance, 0.25 times the usual initial dose at usual intervals; for severe infection, add 0.125 times the usual initial dose after each hemodialysis session
  • hemodialysis: initial, 0.5 to 2 g; maintenance, 0.25 times the usual initial dose at usual intervals; for severe infection, add 0.125 times the usual initial dose after each hemodialysis session
  • geriatrics: dose based on renal function

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Disease due to Gram-negative bacteria
  • Endometritis
  • Female genital infection
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue
  • Infectious disease of abdomen
  • Lower respiratory tract infection
  • Peritonitis
  • Septicemia
  • Urinary tract infectious disease
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Bacterial meningitis
  • Bacterial musculoskeletal infection
  • Febrile neutropenia, Empiric therapy
  • Gonorrhea
  • Postoperative infection; Prophylaxis
  • Traveler's diarrhea

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to aztreonam or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• absence of proven or strongly-suspected infection or use as bacterial prophylaxis; increased risk of developing drug-resistant bacteria
  • allergic reaction, severe without previous exposure to aztreonam; has been reported
  • bone marrow transplant patients with concomitant risk factors (i.e., sepsis, radiation therapy, concomitant use of other drugs associated with toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)); rare cases of TEN reported
  • bronchospasm.
  • clostridium difficile associated diarrhea, including mild diarrhea to fatal colitis; has been reported
  • concomitant administration with aminoglycoside; risk of nephrotoxicity and/or ototoxicity, especially with high doses or prolonged therapy
  • hepatic function, impaired
  • hypersensitivity to beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillins, cephalosporins, carbapenems); increased risk of beta-lactam cross-hypersensitivity reaction
  • pulmonary exacerbation; reduction in forced expiratory volume (FEV) following completion of 28-day regimen (inhalation)
  • renal failure, severe (creatinine clearance less than 10 mL/min/1.73 m(2)); dose reductions required
  • renal insufficiency, transient or persistent (creatinine clearances between 10 mL/min/1.73 m(2) and 30 mL/min/1.73 m(2)); dose adjustments required
  • sensitivity to any allergens, history of; increased risk of hypersensitivity reaction with or without prior exposure.
  • superinfection; may result in overgrowth of nonsusceptible organisms (e.g., gram-positive/negative organisms and fungi)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Chest discomfort (inhalation solution, 8%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (inhalation solution, 7%), Vomiting (inhalation solution, 6%)
  • Hepatic:Alkaline phosphatase raised, ALT/SGPT level raised (pediatrics, 6.5%), AST/SGOT level raised (pediatrics, 3.8%)
  • Renal:Serum creatinine raised (pediatrics, 5.8%)
  • Respiratory:Cough (inhalation solution, 54%), Nasal congestion (inhalation solution, 16%), Pain in throat (inhalation solution, 12%), Wheezing (inhalation solution, 16%)
  • Other:Fever (up to 1%; inhalation, 13%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme (adults, less than 1%), Toxic epidermal necrolysis (adults, less than 1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile colitis, Clostridium difficile diarrhea (adults, less than 1%), Gastrointestinal hemorrhage, Clostridium difficile
  • Hematologic:Neutropenia (up to 3.2%), Pancytopenia (adults, less than 1%), Thrombocytopenia (adults, less than 1%)
  • Hepatic:Hepatitis (adults, less than 1%), Jaundice (adults, less than 1%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (adults, less than 1%)
  • Otic:Ototoxicity
  • Renal:Nephrotoxicity
  • Other:Angioedema (adults, less than 1%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Bactericidal against Gram-negative aerobic bacteria by binding to penicillin-binding protein-3(PBP-3), which results in inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis and often results ultimately in cell lysis and death ; filamentation also occurs in Enterobacteriaceae and P. aeruginosa; does not induce beta-lactamase activity, but has a high degree of stability in the presence of bacterial beta-lactamases; does not bind appreciably to any essential PBPs in gram-positive or anaerobic organisms

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Inhalation: 1 hr
  • Tmax, Intramuscular: 1 hr
  • Bioavailability, Inhalation: low
  • Bioavailability, Oral: less than 1%
  • Bioavailability, Intramuscular: completely
  • Bioavailability, Intraperitoneal: 92%

sub.title: Distribution
sub.mono:
• Vd: 0.11 to 0.21 L/kg (Adults); 0.2 to 0.29 L/kg (Infants and children 1 month to 12 yr); 0.26 to 0.3 L/kg (Neonates less than 1 month); 0.29 to 0.36 L/kg (Premature neonates)
  • Protein binding, Serum: 56 % (inhalation)

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono: 1.4 to 2.2 hr (adults); 1.5 to 1.7 hr (children 1 month to 1 yr); 2.4 to 2.6 hr (neonates less than 1 month); 3.1 to 5.7 hr (premature neonates)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Inhalation
    • do not administer intravenously or intramuscularly
    • do not administer or mix with any other nebulized agent
    • reconstitute with 0.17% sodium chloride diluent supplied
    • administer short-acting bronchodilators 15 min to 4 hours or long-acting bronchodilators 30 min to 12 hours, then any mucolytics prior to aztreonam for inhalation
    • use only with the Altera Nebulizer System(R)
    • administer immediately after reconstitution; do not reconstitute in advance
  • Intramuscular
    • reconstitute vial with at least 3 mL of compatible diluent per g; do not mix with local anesthetic agent
    • inject deep IM into a large muscle mass such as the upper outer quadrant of the gluteus maximus or lateral part of the thigh
  • Intravenous
    • (bolus injection) reconstitute vial with 6 to 10 mL Sterile Water for Injection; shake immediately and vigorously
    • (bolus injection) slowly inject directly into vein or tubing over 3-5 minutes
    • (infusion) reconstitute vial with at least 3 mL Sterile Water for Injection per g; shake immediately and vigorously; dilute further with compatible solution and shake again
    • (infusion) infuse over 20-60 minutes
    • reconstituted solutions are for single dose only; discard unused portion

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• (infection) CBC
  • (infection) resolution of signs and symptoms associated with infection, including fever
  • (cystic fibrosis) improvement in respiratory symptoms (eg, coughing, wheezing, sputum production) and in pulmonary function measured by an increase in FEV1
  • (injection) renal function and creatinine clearance estimation; especially in patients with diminished renal function including the elderly; serum creatinine may not accurately describe renal status
  • (injection) hepatic function; in patients with hepatic impairment

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• The injection formulation of this drug may cause nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. The inhalation formulation may cause cough, nasal congestion, wheezing, sore throat, and fever.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of bronchospasm (inhalation formulation).
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of thrombophlebitis, pancytopenia, or hepatotoxicity.
  • Instruct patient to report severe diarrhea and consult healthcare professional prior to taking anti-diarrhea medicine.
  • Advise patient to use a bronchodilator prior to aztreonam administration (inhalation formulation).
  • Advise patient to take all 3 daily doses as long as doses are at least 4 hours apart (inhalation formulation).
